intro: Dryas octopetala var. asiatica, commonly known as the Asian mountain avens, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the temperate regions of Asia. It is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming structure with hairy stems and basal leaves that are typically lobed or dissected. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers arranged in a cluster of eight, giving it the species name "octopetala." It thrives in well-drained, rocky or sandy soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its ornamental value and hardy nature, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens in cooler climates.
